pli-tv-kd16:17.3.30: If a monk who’s taken on building work disrobes while it’s still unfinished …
pli-tv-kd16:17.3.31: or admits to being a hermaphrodite while it’s still unfinished,
pli-tv-kd16:17.3.32: it should be given to another, with the thought, ‘What belongs to the Sangha shouldn’t be allowed to deteriorate.’
pli-tv-kd16:17.3.33: If a monk who’s taken on building work departs when it’s finished,
pli-tv-kd16:17.3.35: If a monk who’s taken on building work disrobes when it’s finished;
pli-tv-kd16:17.3.36: dies when it’s finished; admits, when it’s finished, to being a novice monk; admits, when it’s finished, to having renounced the training; or admits, when it’s finished, to having committed the worst kind of offense—
pli-tv-kd16:17.3.37: then the Sangha is the owner.
pli-tv-kd16:17.3.38: If a monk who’s taken on building work admits, when it’s finished, to being insane; admits, when it’s finished, to being deranged; admits, when it’s finished, to being overwhelmed by pain; admits, when it’s finished, to having been suspended for not recognizing an offense; admits, when it’s finished, to having been suspended for not making amends for an offense; or admits, when it’s finished, to having been suspended for not giving up a bad view—
pli-tv-kd16:17.3.40: If a monk who’s taken on building work admits, when it’s finished, to being a _paṇḍaka_; admits, when it’s finished, to being a fake monk; admits, when it’s finished, to previously having left to join the monastics of another religion; admits, when it’s finished, to being an animal; admits, when it’s finished, to being a matricide; admits, when it’s finished, to being a patricide; admits, when it’s finished, to being a murderer of a perfected one; admits, when it’s finished, to having raped a nun; admits, when it’s finished, to having caused a schism in the Sangha; admits, when it’s finished, to having caused the Buddha to bleed; or admits, when it’s finished, to being a hermaphrodite—
pli-tv-kd16:17.3.41: then the Sangha is the owner.”
pli-tv-kd16:18.1.0: 3.4 The prohibition against using equipment where it doesn’t belong, etc.
pli-tv-kd16:18.1.1: At one time the monks used a certain lay follower’s equipment where it did not belong.
pli-tv-kd16:18.1.2: That lay follower complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd16:18.1.3: “How can the venerables use the equipment where it doesn’t belong?”
pli-tv-kd16:18.1.5: “You shouldn’t use equipment where it doesn’t belong.
pli-tv-kd16:18.1.6: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd16:18.1.7: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not take any equipment to the observance-day hall or to meetings. They sat down on the bare ground,
pli-tv-kd16:18.1.8: their limbs and robes becoming dirty.
pli-tv-kd16:18.1.11: At that time a large dwelling belonging to the Sangha was decaying.
pli-tv-kd16:18.1.12: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not remove the furniture.
pli-tv-kd16:18.1.14: “I allow you to move it for the purpose of protection.”

pli-tv-kd16:19.1.3: “I allow you to do a beneficial trade.”

pli-tv-kd16:19.1.6: “I allow you to do a beneficial trade.”
pli-tv-kd16:19.1.7: On one occasion the Sangha was offered a bear skin.
pli-tv-kd16:19.1.9: “I allow you to make it into a doormat.”
pli-tv-kd16:19.1.10: On one occasion the Sangha was offered a round pad.
pli-tv-kd16:19.1.12: “I allow you to make it into a doormat.”
pli-tv-kd16:19.1.13: On one occasion the Sangha was offered a cloth.
pli-tv-kd16:19.1.15: “I allow you to make it into a doormat.”
pli-tv-kd16:20.1.1: At that time there were monks who stepped into the dwellings with dirty feet.
pli-tv-kd16:20.1.4: “You shouldn’t step into a dwelling with dirty feet.
pli-tv-kd16:20.1.5: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd16:20.1.9: “You shouldn’t step into a dwelling with wet feet.

pli-tv-kd16:20.2.9: “You should wrap the legs in cloth.”

pli-tv-kd16:20.2.21: “You should spread a sheet and then lie down.”
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.0: 3.5 The allowance for meals for the Sangha, etc.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Āḷavī for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Rājagaha.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.3: he stayed in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.4: At that time Rājagaha was short of food
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.5: and people were unable to make meals for the whole Sangha.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.6: Instead they wished to make meals for designated monks, invitational meals, meals for which lots are drawn, half-monthly meals, meals on the observance day, and meals on the day after the observance day.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.8: “I allow meals for the Sangha, meals for designated monks, invitational meals, meals for which lots are drawn, half-monthly meals, meals on the observance days, and meals on the days after the observance day.”
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.9.0: 3.6 The appointment of a designator of meals
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.9.1: At that time the monks from the group of six took the best meals for themselves and gave the inferior ones to the other monks.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.11: “You should appoint a monk who has five qualities as the designator of meals:
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.12: he’s not biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what has and has not been designated.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.13: And he should be appointed like this.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.14: First a monk should be asked, and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.15: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.16: If the Sangha is ready, it should appoint monk so-and-so as designator of meals.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.18: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.19: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as designator of meals.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.20: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as designator of meals should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.21: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.22: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as designator of meals.
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.23: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.24: The monks who were designator of meals thought,
pli-tv-kd16:21.1.27: “You should mark tickets, make a heap of them, and then designate the meals.”
